cit1.CITATION: Their coordinating properties towards Lewis acids can be fine-tuned over a broad range by means of wellestablished methods of synthetical chemistry, influencing both steric and electronic properties. 1

cit2.CITATION: Moreover, the transition to phosphane oxides and phosphane sulfides alters the Lewis basicity dramatically, rendering those reagents useful as solvating metal extractants in the area of hydrometallurgy. 2

cit3.CITATION: Bulky m-terphenyls form a rigid and concave backbone that has been employed to stabilise both 2′-attached phosphane ligands as well as derived transition metal complexes towards oxidation and dissociation reactions, respectively. 3

cit4.CITATION: The m-terphenyltetracarboxylate motif has been employed in the synthesis of a large number of MOFs, the majority of which were Cu(II)-based systems (see Table S4 †) like the wellknown PCN-305 4 /NJU-Bai10 5 or one of the numerous examples belonging to the ZJNU series. 6

cit5.CITATION: However, concerning the 2′ position of the linker molecule, only examples exhibiting aza-substitution [7] [8] [9] or substitution by structurally simple substituents like amino [10] [11] [12] [13] or methyl groups 6, 14 have come to our attention.

cit6.CITATION: However, concerning the 2′ position of the linker molecule, only examples exhibiting aza-substitution [7] [8] [9] or substitution by structurally simple substituents like amino [10] [11] [12] [13] or methyl groups 6, 14 have come to our attention.

cit14.CITATION: Some P(V)-based frameworks reported to date show exceptional CO 2 uptakes, 15 while the variety of linker molecules employed was, apart from only few notable exceptions, 16, 17 limited to the tri(4-carboxyphenyl)phosphane oxide linker molecule or its elongated analogues. [18] [19] [20]

cit20.CITATION: The PvO functional group was shown to coordinate to the secondary building unit or metal ion via oxygen especially in cases where harder metal ions were employed. [21] [22] [23]

cit21.CITATION: The PvO functional group was shown to coordinate to the secondary building unit or metal ion via oxygen especially in cases where harder metal ions were employed. [21] [22] [23]

cit22.CITATION: The PvO functional group was shown to coordinate to the secondary building unit or metal ion via oxygen especially in cases where harder metal ions were employed. [21] [22] [23]

cit23.CITATION: In case of the medium-hard Cu(II) ion, only two MOFs with the PvO oxygen atom being coordinated 24 and uncoordinated, 25 respectively, were reported.

cit24.CITATION: In case of the medium-hard Cu(II) ion, only two MOFs with the PvO oxygen atom being coordinated 24 and uncoordinated, 25 respectively, were reported.

cit25.CITATION: We felt that substitution by sterically demanding P-based functional groups at the 2′ position might enable for the synthesis of structurally and topologically novel Cu(II) MOFs and intended to investigate whether the combination of open metal sites 26 and polar phosphane oxide functional groups might be beneficial in terms of CO 2 adsorption properties.

cit26.CITATION: The structure of UHM-60 with a composition of Cu 2 L reflecting a neutral framework was elucidated using homology modelling on the UHM-25 27 structure (see ESI † for details).

cit27.CITATION: Based on a structural model obtained from homology modelling, a calculation using the Poreblazer software 28 suggests a void volume of 76% and an accessible specific surface area of 1950 m 2 g -1.

cit28.CITATION: The linker identity was examined via 1 H and 31 P{ 1 H} NMR spectroscopy on an acid-digested sample of UHM-61.

cit29.CITATION: Within UHM-60/UHM-61 as well as an isoreticular Cu(II)based MOF by Zaworotko and co-workers 29 and the UHM-25 class materials reported by our group, 27 the tip of the 'V' of the V-shaped linker extends into the red-type pores, thus being averted from the volume of green-type pores.

cit30.CITATION: Within UHM-60/UHM-61 as well as an isoreticular Cu(II)based MOF by Zaworotko and co-workers 29 and the UHM-25 class materials reported by our group, 27 the tip of the 'V' of the V-shaped linker extends into the red-type pores, thus being averted from the volume of green-type pores.

cit31.CITATION: The underlying net of UHM-60 and UHM-61 can be described as binodal (3,4)-c ucp with minimal transitivity 30 pqrs = 2244.

cit32.CITATION: The molecular (non-periodic) relative to the cuboctahedron shown in Fig. 3b, MOP-1, which is constructed from isophthalate ligands coordinated to Cu(II) paddle-wheels, was already presented in 2002. 31

cit33.CITATION: O’Keeffe and Yaghi proposed diﬀerent ways to interconnect cuboctahedra, depending on whether neighbouring cuboctahedra point at each other in a face-to-face (A), vertex-to-vertex (B), or vertex-to-face fashion (C). 32

cit34.CITATION: We discussed the implications of linker conformation on the resulting type of interconnectivity of neighbouring cuboctahedra earlier 27 and will expand this approach later herein.

cit35.CITATION: Shortest inter-paddle-wheel distances for MOFs based on the m-terphenyl tetracarboxylate linker molecule have been found for Zn(II)-based (Zn⋯Zn = 3.751(4) Å) and Mn(II)-based (Mn⋯Mn = 3.892(2) Å) materials. 33

cit36.CITATION: In Zhou and co-workers' PCN-88, which is isoreticular to UHM-62/UHM-63 (see section below) employing the elongated 2,7-bis(3′,5′-dicarboxyphenyl)naphthalene linker molecule, an inter-paddle-wheel Cu⋯Cu distance of 7.3655(12) Å was found. 34

cit37.CITATION: Recently, the PCN-88 topology was first found within a Cu(II) m-terphenyl tetracarboxylatebased material BUT-301 35 by employing the 5′-NO2-substituted linker molecule with Cu⋯Cu = 4.7575(13) Å and a μ2-chlorideion. In addition, we are aware of only few examples with axially cross-linked Cu(II) paddle-wheels of 3-periodic MOFs where the link is provided by a chloride anion 36 (Cu⋯Cu = 4.550(3) Å) or an oxygen-type ligand.

cit38.CITATION: Recently, the PCN-88 topology was first found within a Cu(II) m-terphenyl tetracarboxylatebased material BUT-301 35 by employing the 5′-NO2-substituted linker molecule with Cu⋯Cu = 4.7575(13) Å and a μ2-chlorideion. In addition, we are aware of only few examples with axially cross-linked Cu(II) paddle-wheels of 3-periodic MOFs where the link is provided by a chloride anion 36 (Cu⋯Cu = 4.550(3) Å) or an oxygen-type ligand.

cit39.SECTION: Carbon dioxide and methane physisorption and selectivities
cit39.CITATION: The chemical nature of the PvO bond is not sufficiently described in terms of a simple Lewis structure, as Gilheany pointed out in an influential review. 38

cit40.SECTION: Carbon dioxide and methane physisorption and selectivities
cit40.CITATION: The highest adsorption enthalpies have been reported for materials with 5′-F-2′-NH 2 (39.5 kJ mol -1), 40 2′-NH 2 (37.51 kJ mol -1), 11 and 2′-aza-functionalized m-terphenyls (36.9 kJ mol -1), 9 indicating a strong interaction between the nitrogen-based functional groups and CO2.

cit52.CITATION: For PCN-88, Qst = 27 kJ mol−1 and a capacity of 94 cm3 g -1 (296 K) were reported. 34

cit53.SECTION: Carbon dioxide and methane physisorption and selectivities
cit53.CITATION: The ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) 45 was used to calculate the CO 2 /CH 4 selectivities of UHM-62 at 298 K and 273 K, respectively (Fig. 5c).

cit54.SECTION: Carbon dioxide and methane physisorption and selectivities
cit54.CITATION: Within the group of Cu(II)-based m-terphenyl MOFs, best selectivities were determined for anionic JLU-Liu22 46 (9.4 at 298 K) and a cationic MOF 9 (30.8 at 298 K).

cit55.SECTION: Carbon dioxide and methane physisorption and selectivities
cit55.CITATION: Within the group of Cu(II)-based m-terphenyl MOFs, best selectivities were determined for anionic JLU-Liu22 46 (9.4 at 298 K) and a cationic MOF 9 (30.8 at 298 K).

cit56.SECTION: Conformations of m-terphenyl diisophthalates and topology of derived Cu(II)-based MOFs
cit56.CITATION: An evaluation of literature-known three-periodic MOFs employing the m-terphenyl diisophthalate linker molecule and its substituted derivatives (Table S4 †) has shown that there is, apart from only relatively few exceptions that came to our attention, 8, 9, 35, [47] [48] [49] a strong preference to form structures with underlying mfj or sty topologies, with the first examples reported in literature being the PCN-305 to PCN-308 series 4 for mfj and a material that has been prepared by post-synthetic metal ion exchange of Zn(II) for Cu(II) for sty. 11

cit57.SECTION: Conformations of m-terphenyl diisophthalates and topology of derived Cu(II)-based MOFs

cit65.SECTION: Conformations of m-terphenyl diisophthalates and topology of derived Cu(II)-based MOFs
cit65.CITATION: For the examples of MOFs showing underlying nets not belonging to the four topologies discussed before, combinations of twist and fold contributions lying outside the ranges defined for mfj, sty, ucp, and 3,3,4,4T199 are observed, except for one example with an underlying topology characterised by a point symbol {6 2 •8 2 •12 2 }{6 2 •8} 4 {6 4 •8 2 } showing only a twisted conformation of the linker molecule. 8
